user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of add_response_entry:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
add_response_entry (struct MHD_Response *response,
                    enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                    const char *header,
                    const char *content)
{
  size_t header_len;
  size_t content_len;

  if (NULL == content)
    return MHD_NO;

  header_len = strlen (header);
  content_len = strlen (content);
  return add_response_entry_n (response, kind, header,
                               header_len, content,
                               content_len) ? MHD_YES : MHD_NO;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no code fragments that are demonstrably unreachable (i.e., code that can never execute) in this function. The early return if (NULL == content) is a reachable control-flow path when content is NULL; the remaining statements (strlen(header); strlen(content); and the final return with the ternary) are reachable when content is non-NULL. Both outcomes of the ternary operator depend on the runtime result of add_response_entry_n and therefore are reachable. There is no code after an unconditional return, no constant-false/constant-true condition that makes a block permanently dead, and no unconditional infinite loop that prevents later statements from executing. Note: there is a potential robustness/undefined-behavior concern (header is not NULL-checked before calling strlen), but that is not an instance of unreachable code (MISRA C Rule 2.1) and thus not included as a suspicious fragment for this rule.
